concepts.definition: A binary tree where a node's left child must have a key less than its parent, and a node's right child must have a key greater than or equal to its parent.
To traverse a tree means to visit all the nodes in some specified order. There are three simple ways: inorder, preorder, and postorder.
Visits the left child, then the node itself, then the right child. An inorder traversal of a binary search tree will cause all the nodes to be visited in ascending order.
Visits the node itself, then the node's left subtree, and finally the node's right subtree.
Traverses the node's left subtree, then the right subtree, and finally visits the node itself.
